sections.passage:
Reading Comprehension Review


Kite Power
“There is incredible power in the wind,” according to inventor Saul Griffith. He estimates that wind has more than enough power to provide for our global energy needs 200 times over. Now, an idea from a child’s toy may help to harness1 this power.
Towering 300 feet (90 meters) above the Earth’s surface, wind turbines are the most visible—and common—way to harness the power of the wind. Wind power is becoming an important source of energy today. Population growth means we have a greater need for energy, especially energy that does not add to global warming. According to the U.S. Department of Energy, one megawatt of wind energy can provide power for up to 400 homes without producing any carbon dioxide—a source of global warming.
While wind is a promising energy source, there are problems with traditional turbines. First of all, they’re expensive. This is because they’re made from costly materials such as steel and fiberglass2. In addition, they’re only useful in places where the wind travels routinely at around 15–20 miles per hour. Only about 15 percent of land in the world has winds this strong. Turbines are already very tall, but to reach the faster wind speeds at even higher altitudes, they would have to be taller. But at the moment, it’s not practical to build these taller turbines.
Inventor Saul Griffith got an idea from a wind-powered toy—the kite—to solve some of these problems. Griffith is developing an “energy kite,” that is tethered3 to the ground. It flies in large circles up to 1,000 feet (300 meters) in the air. At this altitude, the wind is stronger and more consistent than at lower altitudes. The energy kite has blades like a regular turbine, so it generates electricity in a similar way.
Griffith’s invention has some advantages over a traditional turbine. First of all, it’s lighter. For example, the shaft is made of plastic, which is cheap to make. It can also generate more than twice as much wind power as a traditional turbine. Finally, because most of the energy kite is in the air, it takes up less land than a traditional turbine. It also works over water, where wind moves at even greater speeds.
Griffith says his invention has brought us to “the dawn of a new age of kites. ” He and his team are planning even bigger energy kites that could generate huge amounts of clean electricity. While he is still at the prototype stage, the early tests are promising. Griffith believes his energy kite will be an important part of the solution to our current climate and energy problems.
1harness: v. to capture the power of something
2fiberglass: n. a material made from glass fibers
3tether: v. to hold in place using a rope

sections.passage:
Reading Comprehension Extension

Two Kinds of Power
People look to various sources—gas, coal, nuclear energy, geothermal energy, and wind power— to fuel the world’s growing need for electricity. Nuclear energy and wind power seem to be very different in terms of how much energy they produce, and how safe people perceive them to be. 
One nuclear power plant produces the same amount of electricity per year as over 2000 wind turbines. An average wind farm has about 30 turbines. This works out to 60 wind farms per one nuclear power plant. A nuclear power plant is capable of producing energy constantly, whereas wind turbines require the right weather conditions to be effective. In terms of being a reliable source of electricity, nuclear power has the advantage.
However, nuclear power is perceived to be much more dangerous. If there is some kind of leak or explosion, nuclear power plants can release harmful radioactive particles into the air.  These particles can cause cancer or other illnesses. People are required to live one mile away from a nuclear power plant. In case of an accident, people who live within 50 miles of the plant are evacuated.
This is in contrast to the relatively safe wind farms. There is no risk of radiation from a wind turbine. The biggest problem may be the noise the turbines produce. Researchers are finding that long-term exposure to such noise can cause hearing damage. But in general, it would be much safer to live next to a wind farm than a nuclear power plant.
Neither source of energy is perfect though scientists seek to improve upon them.  Technological advances have made nuclear power plants safer. Inventors, like Saul Griffith,” are attempting to harness wind power more effectively through devices such as the “energy kite.” Perhaps over time, the two sources will be equally safe and efficient.

options: to compare two kinds of energy

sections.passage:
Reading Skills

The Rise of Drones
More and more drones are being used by military forces throughout the world.  These “unmanned aircraft” are replacing traditional, manned aircraft.  The number one reason drones are used is to save lives.  No pilots or other air crew are lost when a drone is shot down.  Similar to traditional aircraft, some drones carry weapons while others have hi-tech equipment used for information gathering.  Another advantage of drones is that they can stay in the air for longer periods of time.  They may also be cheaper to build.  One serious concern with drones is that they are not as precise as manned aircraft in hitting targets.  Reports show that drones may kill more civilians than manned aircraft.

deadlyexpensive
manned
military
pilots

Drones that shoot weapons may be more _______________________ to civilians because they are not as accurate as manned aircraft.
Some drones are less _______________________ to build than traditional aircraft.

sections.instructions: DIRECTIONS: Read the following excerpts from William Kamkwamba’s TED Talk. Then read the statements and select True or False.
sections.passage:
TED Talk Comprehension



William Kamkwamba—How I Harnessed the Wind

Thank you. Two years ago, I stood on the TED stage in Arusha, Tanzania. I spoke very briefly about one of my proudest creations. It was a simple machine that changed my life.
Before that time, I had never been away from my home in Malawi. I had never used a computer. I had never seen an Internet. On the stage that day, I was so nervous. My English lost, I wanted to vomit. I had never been surrounded by so many azungu, white people.
One year, our fortune turned very bad. In 2001, we experienced an awful famine. Within five months all Malawians began to starve to death. My family ate one meal per day, at night. Only three swallows of nsima for each one of us. The food passes through our bodies. We drop down to nothing.
. . . Another book put that knowledge in my hands. It said a windmill could pump water and generate electricity. Pump water meant irrigation, a defense against hunger, which we were experiencing by that time. So I decided I would build one windmill for myself. But I didn’t have materials to use, so I went to a scrap yard where I found my materials. Many people, including my mother, said I was crazy.
I found a tractor fan, shock absorber, PVC pipes. Using a bicycle frame and an old bicycle dynamo, I built my machine. It was one light at first. And then four lights, with switches, and even a circuit breaker, modeled after an electric bell. Another machine pumps water for irrigation.

items.q: During his first speech, William Kamkwamba felt very nervous.
During the famine, 2001 Malawians starved to death.
In 2001, Kamkwamba’s family ate only one meal every day.
William Kamkwamba found a way to generate electricity.
Kamkwamba’s mother taught him how to build things like windmills.
